name: Moderator Beth Anne
comment info:
Thanks to all the students who responded.   

Here are some of the catchy headlines that we received: "Headline: America running on gas, can't keep up with the electric car movement." by Grace at Academy of Saint Elizabeth in New Jersey, “The U.S. Falls Behind in the Race of Electric Vehicle Sales” by Max of Eleanor Roosevelt High School in New York City and “Electric Car Takeover in Europe and China! The U.S. Trying to Catch Up” by Carlos of Perth Amboy High School in New Jersey.  Note that these headlines focus on comparing the electric car sales taking over car sales with the US lagging.  This is what is so surprising about these graphs. 

Please return on Friday when we will reveal the free links to the articles that include these graphs.  Also in the Reveal are a summary of the topic, additional questions, shout outs for some of the best headlines for the graph and Stat Nuggets -- definitions of words that relate to the graph and where you can find them in the graph.

comment info:
This graph represents the percentage of car purchases that were fully electric vehicles from 2010 to 2022. From 2010 to 2016, the percentage of electric cars purchased from the U.S., E.U., and China, were all under 5%. After 2016, the purchase of electric cars began to increase drastically. I wonder what was the sudden boom for Chinese electric vehicle purchasers between 2020 and 2021 considering the total percentage rose around 10%. With COVID-19 still being very apparent and production being slow globally, how was the Chinese population receiving these cars? In my community, I see the rise of electric cars more and more every day. Because of rising gas prices and the amount of driving my parents do due to work, in the past year my family has purchased two fully electric cars. I know that other families in my area, with most adults commuting into New York City for work, have turned to electric or hybrid vehicles for their long-term cost-effectiveness. name: Sana Goyal
comment info:
I notice that these bar graphs depict the rise in sales of electric cars through the years for the US, the European Union, and China. The biggest percent increases have occurred in the most recent years (approximately 2019-2022). Additionally, the EU and China have both seen exponential growth in their sales, while sales in the United States have grown linearly. 

I wonder why China and the European Union have substantially more electric car sales than the United States, despite the US being one of the top car manufacturing countries, second only to China (OICA 2021). I wonder if it's because of the different incentives some countries offer to owners of electric cars. For example, in the EU, electric car drivers pay no purchase taxes or VAT on electric cars, benefit from free parking, and are exempt from all road tolls. Additionally, China unveiled a 520 billion yuan package of tax breaks over four years for electric vehicles (EVs) and other green cars. 

This affects my community because, as a citizen of the United States, I worry about the environmental impact my country has on the world. Without incentives like the ones in the EU and China, many in the US cannot afford electric or hybrid cars, as they are generally more expensive than regular gas cars. This not only gives the US a reputation for high pollution, but it also causes a disproportionate amount of air pollution in lower-income areas, which can lead to health hazards. 

Title: The US Left in the Dust?
